title-group.article-title: The Challenge of Developing a New Predictive Formula to Estimate Energy Requirements in Ventilated Critically Ill Children

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Paediatrics, Imperial College, London, UK
2Statistical Advisory Service, Imperial College, London, UK
4University College London and Department of Children’s Nursing, London South Bank University, London, UK

author-notes.corresp: Rosan Meyer, Department of Paediatrics, Division Medicine, Imperial College, St Mary’s Campus, London, W2 1PG, UK; e-mail: rmeyer@imperial.ac.uk.

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition
permissions.copyright-holder: The American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition

abstract.p: Background: Traditionally, energy requirements have been calculated using predictive equations. These methods have failed to calculate energy expenditure accurately. Routine indirect calorimetry has been suggested, but this method is technically demanding and costly. This study aimed to develop a new predictive equation to estimate energy requirements for critically ill children. Methods: This prospective, observational study on ventilated children included patients with an endotracheal tube leak of <10% and fractional inspired oxygen of <60%. An indirect calorimetry energy expenditure measurement was performed and polynomial regression analysis was used to develop new predictive equations. The new formulas were then compared with existing prediction equations. Results: Data from 369 measurements were included in the formula design. Only weight and diagnosis influenced energy expenditure significantly. Three formulas (A, B, C) with an R2 > 0.8 were developed. When we compared the new formulas with commonly used equations (Schofield, Food and Agriculture Organization/World Health Organization/United Nations University, and White equation), all formulas performed very similar, but the Schofield equation seemed to have the lowest SD. Conclusions: All 3 new pediatric intensive care unit equations have R2 values of >0.8; however, the Schofield equation still performed better than other predictive methods in predicting energy expenditure in these patients. Still, none of the predictive equations, including the new equations, predicted energy expenditure within a clinically accepted range, and further research is required, particularly for patients outside the technical scope of indirect calorimetry.

body.p: Protein energy malnutrition (PEM) is common in pediatric intensive care units (PICUs).1-3 Even at the time of hospital admission, a significant proportion (24%) of critically ill children have acute or chronic PEM.1,4 The effects include increased morbidity and length of hospital stay due to impaired muscle strength,5 reduced wound healing as a result of altered immunity,2 and augmented rates of sepsis.6,7 Although undernutrition is more common in ventilated critically ill children, the risk of overfeeding8 has also been well documented. Providing excess nutrients, especially carbohydrates,9 may lead to increased carbon dioxide (CO2) production, which may result in difficulties weaning from mechanical ventilation. In addition, increased lipogenesis related to overfeeding may alter body composition, and diarrhea from nutrient excess may be associated with electrolyte imbalances.8,10,11

Traditionally, energy requirements are calculated using predictive equations.12,13 However, these methods fail to calculate energy expenditure within acceptable accuracy, leading to the over- or underprediction of energy requirements.14,15 Consequently, a measurement of energy expenditure remains the most accurate method of calculating resting energy expenditure. Indirect calorimetry is often used for this purpose in pediatrics.16 However, this method is technically demanding, time-consuming, and costly, and the interpretation of measurement output can be difficult.17 A recent survey showed that only 17% of PICUs in Europe had access to indirect calorimeter equipment,18 and hence its routine use is not feasible for most units.18-20 The problems with the current predictive equations and the lack of availability of indirect calorimetry are likely to result in continued under- or overfeeding in many critically ill children, with the associated morbidity. We therefore set out to develop a new predictive equation to estimate energy requirements for ventilated critically ill children and compare its accuracy with previously published equations.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A prospective, observational study was performed from May 2005 to August 2008 on critically ill children admitted to the PICUs at Imperial College Healthcare National Health Service (NHS) Trust and Royal Brompton Hospital NHS Trust. These units specialize in children with cardiac disorders, infectious diseases, respiratory failure, and neurodevelopmental disorders. Because these 2 PICUs do not admit patients with liver disease, additional energy expenditure data were obtained from collaborators at Kings College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust London who had also prospectively collected energy expenditure data using the same methodology, instrument and the same variable data.21 The second stage of this study was to compare the new formula with commonly used predictive equations in a cohort of patients admitted to the PICUs at Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust and the Royal Brompton Hospital. Local ethics approval has been obtained for this study.

The same inclusion and exclusion criteria were used for measurements performed in all 3 PICUs: all ventilated critically ill children (full-term delivery to 16 years) were eligible for inclusion, except for children on bolus enteral feeds (increases thermic effect of food), on renal replacement therapy, with an endotracheal tube leak (ETT-leak) of more than 10% [(inspired tidal volume – expired tidal volume/inspired tidal volume) × 100], with a fractional inspired oxygen (FiO2) level above 0.6, and ventilated with heliox, nitric oxide, or high-frequency oscillatory ventilation.22-24 In addition, those children who were eligible for inclusion but did not achieve steady state and/or had incomplete data sets were also excluded from the final data analysis.

Information that was included in this study and data analysis were chosen from variables included in several previously published pediatric and adult energy expenditure equations for intensive care, including the Ireton-Jones equation25 and formulas by White et al26 and Pierro et al.27 In addition, factors in which previous data on their impact on energy expenditure had been ambiguous were also included. Patient information on age, gender, and admission weight was collected and weight-for-age z scores calculated. If it was not possible to obtain an accurate admission weight, the last weight in the patients’ growth charts, which are compulsory for all children in the NHS in the United Kingdom, was used. Supine length/height was not included as a variable in this study because of the difficulty in measuring this accurately on an intensive care unit. For the purpose of data analysis, age was categorized into the same 3 categories as the Schofield equation28): <3 years (category 1), 3–10 years (category 2), and 11–18 years (category 3). The day of admission was documented and patients’ primary diagnosis was recorded and then categorized into multiorgan system failure (MOSF)29 using the criteria from Goldstein et al29 or single-organ failure, which included respiratory, cardiac, central nervous system (CNS), gastrointestinal, surgical, and liver failure. The single-organ failure categories were generated from the Paediatric Intensive Care Audit Network in the United Kingdom, and patients were categorized according to the predominant diagnostic reason for being admitted onto the PICU.30 The Paediatric Logistic Organ Dysfunction (PELOD) score was used as a marker of severity of illness and was calculated for the day of measurement.31 Axillary temperature was measured during the energy expenditure measurement and categorized into 3 categories: temp 1, ≤37.3°C; temp 2, 37.4°C–38.4°C; and temp 3, ≥38.4°C. In addition the presence of medication related to sedation, neuromuscular blockade, and inotropic support was also documented.

Measurements were performed using the Deltatrac II NMN-200 (Datex Ohmeda, Helsinki, Finland) indirect calorimeter, which has previously been validated in critically ill children.32,33 The Deltatrac II was calibrated at the start of the study, using the quantitative alcohol-burning process, and repeated 6 monthly. Prior to each measurement, the Deltatrac II was warmed up for 30 minutes, and gas sensor calibration was performed using the recommended gas mixture from Datex Ohmeda (5% CO2 and 95% O2).34 Energy expenditure data were recorded only after steady state had been achieved, which was defined by 5 consecutive 1-minute measurements with ≤10% variation in volume of inspired oxygen (VO2) and volume of expired carbon dioxide (VCO2).35-37 Thirty minutes of energy expenditure measurements were then carried for each patient, once in steady state. During the collection of energy expenditure data, no invasive procedures or ventilator setting changes took place unless clinically indicated. If procedures had to be performed during a measurement, the energy expenditure data were discarded.

Statistical software SPSS 17.0 (SPSS, Inc, an IBM Company, Chicago, IL) and Epi Info Version 3.3.2 (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Atlanta, GA) were used to analyze the data for the study. Polynomial regression analysis was used to establish the impact of individual variables on energy expenditure and to develop the new predictive equation. Variables were included or excluded from the final model based on whether the variable on its own or in combination with another variable had a significant (P < .05) impact on energy expenditure. Type III sum-of-squares method was used because this statistical method corresponds to the variation attributable to an effect after correcting for any other effects in the model. Although the data from the 3 centers were analyzed together, we also assessed whether the regression analysis was biased, with the inclusion of the data from the third center (Kings College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust London), by comparing the R2 value from the 2 centers with the 3 centers. This center also contributed the majority of repeated measurements, and we used the R2 value to assess whether the repeated measurements had an impact on the prediction model. We aimed to develop a formula that would predict energy expenditure accurately in 80% of cases (R2 ≥ 0.8). The R2 value (coefficient of determination) of the new formula was compared with the values from the Schofield, World Health Organization (WHO), and White equations. Statistical significance, where quoted, is at a 5% level (P < .05), and other results are presented in means, confidence intervals (CIs), and standard deviations (SD). To determine the limits of agreement between the new predictive formulas, existing equations, and measured energy expenditure (MEE), the method described by Bland and Altman was used; in addition, percentiles of relative differences between the predictive formulas and MEE were also calculated.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Data for 175 patients with 369 energy expenditure measurements were included in the design of the formulas. From the 175 patients, 56 had repeated measurements and originated mainly from the data from Kings College Hospital NHS Trust. The above number of recruited patients excludes the 23 children who were enrolled in the study but for whom steady state was not achieved, and 7 children did not have a complete data set, which was mainly due to unavailable blood results and Glasgow Coma Scale required for the PELOD score. In total, 175 patients were included in the final analysis: 100 from Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust, 21 from the Brompton Hospital, and 54 from the Kings College Hospital database. Patient characteristics are described in Table 1. The majority of patients had a respiratory or central nervous system diagnosis. Because of the small number of patients with an admission diagnosis of gastrointestinal disease (n = 3), this group was excluded from data analysis as this number was insufficient to yield significant information on the impact of gastrointestinal disease as a diagnosis on energy expenditure. The majority of measurements (n = 166, 45%) were performed in patients younger than 3 years, 88 measurements (23.8%) were performed in children aged 3–10 years, and 115 (31.2%) were performed in 11- to 18-year-olds. In 28% (n = 49) of children, an accurate admission weight was not obtained, and their last weight from their growth records was recorded. However, this did not significantly affect the results of the study as the exclusion of children without an accurate admission weight yielded a lower R2 value (0.814).

caption.p: Characteristics of Patients Whose Data Were Included in the Development of the New Predictive Equations

fn.p: CNS, central nervous system; MOSF, multiorgan system failure; NHS, National Health Service; PELOD = Paediatric Logistic Organ Dysfunction.

sec.p: Regression analysis indicated that inotropes (P = .77), neuromuscular blockade (P = .923), temperature (P = .133), severity of disease measured by PELOD score (P = .794), C-reactive protein (P = .604), and the day of measurement (P = .976) did not have a significant impact on energy expenditure, and those variables were therefore excluded from further analysis. Three formulas were developed from our data with an R2 > 0.8 (Table 2): formula A (R2 = 0.833) was developed from the data generated from the PICUs at Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust and Royal Brompton Hospital NHS Trust. Formula B (R2 = 0.839) was developed using data from the 3 sites, including patients with liver disease. Formula C (R2 = 0.829) was the most simplified formula, generated from all 3 sites, which did not include diagnostic categories as a variable. The R2 values between using 2 (R2 = 0.833) versus 3 sites did not differ significantly (R2 = 0.839), which indicated that the modeling was not biased, using the prospective data collected by Kings College Hospital, and the repeated measurements also did not reduce the R2 value. We also calculated the coefficient of determination (R2) for other existing predictive equations using the energy expenditure data from our cohort: Schofield, R2 = 0.815; WHO formula, R2 = 0.763; and White formula, R2 = 0.806.

caption.p: Three Predictive Equations (A, B, and C) for Resting Energy Expenditure of Ventilated Critically Ill Children and Their Respective R2 Value

fn.label: c
fn.p: Diagnostic category and weight in kg.

sec.p: A further 30 patients were recruited to compare the performance of other commonly used formulas with our new predictive equations. Eighteen patients were in the 0- to 3-year age category, 7 in the 3- to 10-year age group, and 5 in the 11- to 18-year age group. Their characteristics were as follows: 17 males and 13 females, median age of 51.6 months (range, 0–196 months), mean (SD) weight of 15.49 (14.21) kg, and mean temperature of 37.2°C (Table 3).

caption.p: Characteristics of the Patients Recruited to Compare Against Different Formulas

tr.td: Number of patients in each diagnostic category

fn.p: CNS, central nervous system; MOSF, multiorgan system failure; PELOD = Paediatric Logistic Organ Dysfunction.

sec.p: Energy expenditure measurements were on average performed on day 3 of the PICU admission, and the mean energy expenditure was 41.66 kcal/kg/d. The mean PELOD score for patients was 13.1, which was comparable to the severity of disease score (PELOD of 12) of patients included in the development of the formulas. Patients had the following diagnoses: respiratory failure (n = 11), CNS disorders (n = 6), cardiac failure (n = 6), surgery (n = 3), and MOSF (n = 4).

The Bland-Altman method used in this study to compare limits of agreement between the mean MEE, the new equations (A, B, and C), Schofield basal metabolic rate (BMR), the Food and Agriculture Organization/World Health Organization/United Nations University (FAO/WHO/UNU) equation, and the White equation indicated that the standard deviation for all equations, except for the equation by White et al,26 ranged from 136.8–196.2 kcal/d and performed very similar, as summarized in Table 4. However, the Schofield equation had the lowest standard deviation (136.8 kcal/d), and the 95% CI ranged between –74.2 and 27.8 kcal/d. According to this method, the equation by White et al performed the worst, with a standard deviation of 324.7 kcal/d and 95% CI of –16. 31 to 226.2 kcal. The Bland-Altman plots also indicated for all equations, except for the equation by White et al, that there was a scatter close to the mean below 1000 kcal but then a wider scatter above 1000 kcal. Figure 1 provides an example of the Bland-Altman plot for equation B compared with MEE and the FAO/WHO/UNU also compared with MEE.

caption.p: Standard Deviation and 95% Confidence Interval Between Measured Energy Expenditure and the Different Predictive Equations as Established by the Bland-Altman Method of Comparison

fn.p: FAO/WHO/UNU, Food and Agriculture Organization/World Health Organization/United Nations University; PICU, pediatric intensive care unit.

caption.p: Examples of Bland-Altman plots comparing the Food and Agriculture Organization/World Health Organization/United Nations University (FAO/WHO/UNU) equation and equation B with the measured energy expenditure (MEE), demonstrating the scatter around the mean <1000 kcal and the wider scatter >1000 kcal, which is similar to all other equations.

sec.p: In addition, the percentile differences between formulas show that 25% of patients had predicted energy expenditure within 10% of actual requirements with all equations except for the White formula, which differed by up to 82% (max) from the MEE. In 75% of cases, the predicted energy expenditure varied by 26%–29% from the MEE, except for the White equation (Table 5).

caption.p: Percentiles of Relative Differences Between the Predictive Formulas and the Measured Energy Expenditure

fn.p: At the 75th percentile (75% of all children), all formulas except for the White formula predicted energy expenditure that differed by 26% to 29% from the measured energy expenditure. BMR, basal metabolic rate; WHO, World Health Organization.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The objective of this study was to develop a new predictive equation specifically designed for energy expenditure in critically ill children and to compare its accuracy with previously published formulas. Our aim was to achieve a formula with an R2 value above 0.8, using variables that are routinely used on the PICU. Three equations were developed, including the variables of age and weight, with or without diagnostic categories, and R2 values of 0.833 (equation A), 0.839 (equation B), and 0.829 (equation C). At present, only one other predictive equation has been published specifically for ventilated critically ill children.26 The formula developed by White et al26 was derived from a data set of 100 patients and had an R2 value of 0.898. In our patient group, the White formula performed less well (R2 = 0.806). We also compared values for R2 for the Schofield (0.815) and WHO formulas (0.763) with our values for R2 of our new predictive equations, which had a better statistical predictive value. Contrary to the limited number of predictive equations developed for ventilated critically ill children, many such equations have been published for ventilated adults. These include the Ireton-Jones, Frankenfield, Swinamer, and Penn-State equations.25 The original Ireton-Jones equation, commonly used for ventilated critically ill adults, has a much lower value R2 value of 0.43, as do the Swinamer and Frankenfield equations (R2 = 0.76538 and R2 = 0.77,39 respectively). We therefore conclude that our PICU equations have acceptable statistical predictive values when compared with other published formulas.

Predictive models for energy expenditure in critically ill patients have been developed using various independent variables, of which weight and age are the most commonly used. Other independent variables include body surface area, temperature, diagnosis, gender, spontaneous or nonspontaneous breathing, respiratory rate, tidal volume, or heart rate.25,27 Although inclusion of variables in any predictive equation is mainly driven by statistical analyses, variables often have been excluded from previous predictive formulas due to ambiguity or impracticality. For example, the formula with the highest correlation in the study by White et al26 included weight, weight-for-age z score, temperature, days on PICU, and diagnostic category. The authors of that study eliminated weight-for-age z score because it was not practical to calculate this at the bedside, and their simplified formulas performed just as well without day of admission. Diagnosis was also not included in that formula because of possible ambiguity in defining diagnostic category.26 In our present study, equations A and B, the formulas with the highest R2 values, included actual weight and age as variables, in addition to diagnostic category, because our study suggested this as an important contributor to energy expenditure. The only other formulas that include diagnosis as a variable are the Ireton-Jones and Frankenfield equations for ventilated adults.40 These contain a factor for trauma, burns, and sepsis.38,40 We also found that severity of disease (P = .794) did not affect energy expenditure. This concurs with several previously published studies.15,41,42

Interestingly, our study did not show an association between the patients’ temperature and the MEE, in contrast to other predictive formulas that have included temperature as an independent variable.26 A possible explanation may be the individual maximum level of O2 consumption, discussed by Turi et al9 and Verhoeven et al,43 normally found in critically ill children; as temperature rises, there is not an equivalent increase in VO2 and therefore no elevated energy expenditure.44,45 Recently, McHoney et al46 found altered intraoperative thermoregulation in children undergoing laparoscopic surgery, which affected resting energy expenditure (REE) 4 hours after the procedure, but no difference was found at 24 hours. Our study included only 8 postsurgical patients, who had both laparoscopic and open procedures and were not measured within 4 hours of the procedure; we would therefore not see this impact on REE. From a practical perspective, the omission of temperature from a predictive formula makes it easier to use since temperature varies during the day, which implies the predictive equation would need to be recalculated as temperature changes.

Our new equations were also compared with the REE predicted by the Schofield, WHO, and White equations in 30 patients. All 3 formulas performed very similar, with both standard deviation and the 95% CI within a comparable range, but the Schofield formula yielded the best results, with a standard deviation of 136.8 kcal/d (Table 4). It is an interesting finding that, according to the Bland-Altman plots, the limits of agreement are better below 1000 kcal, thus implying that the prediction accuracy for the new predictive equation in particular is better for younger children. This is probably related to the majority of our data being generated from children <3 years of age. The equation by White et al26 performed the worst and differed by up to 82% from the MEE. Only 25% of patients had a predicted energy expenditure within <10% variation using the different formulas (excluding the White equation), which concurs with a recent systematic review of predictive equations for ventilated adults, which indicated that only 28% of patients had their energy expenditure predicted within 10% of measured requirements.25 None of the equations, including the new equations, predict energy expenditure within acceptable limits of agreement in all patients.

The main limitation of our study is related to the number of patients we recruited in the different age categories to develop our prediction equations. The majority of patient data included came from children younger than 3 years. Although this very much reflects admissions in PICUs in Europe, our formulas have been designed to cover ages 0–18 years. The large number of patients in age category 1 (<3 years) may have biased our formulas toward this age category. Further energy expenditure data are therefore required to be collected in age groups 3–10 and 11–18 years from children with a variety of diagnoses to improve the accuracy of the formulas.

Another limitation is the number and case mix of patients included in our study, comparing the new formulas with existing formulas. Although a larger patient cohort would have allowed us to establish the accuracy of the new formula with greater power, it is noteworthy that other studies have validated similar formulas with a small number of patients (25 patients in White et al26 and 13 additional studies on 9 patients in Pierro et al27).

The comparison cohort also did not include patients within the liver disease diagnostic category, which may have biased our results in favor of formula A. Further comparison of the performance of the new formulas (especially formulas B and C) should also take place within this group of patients.

Another limitation is related to the technical constraints of indirect calorimetry itself. Patients on renal replacement therapy, those requiring high-frequency oscillation or nitric oxide, and patients with an FiO2 level above 0.6 were excluded from the study due its impact on indirect calorimeter measurements.47 Hemofiltration or high-frequency oscillatory ventilation is often required in children at the more extreme level of disease severity, and patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome frequently have an FiO2 above 0.6.23 Consequently, some children with the worst disease severity were often not enrolled in the study. Arguably, those patients are the most vulnerable and at risk of acute PEM.48,49 There is very limited research on energy expenditure in patients who are beyond the technical capabilities of indirect calorimetry. Jaksic et al50 and Keshen et al51 used stable isotopes in critically ill neonates receiving extracorporeal membrane oxygenation and found these patients to be mildly hypermetabolic. Until further studies have taken place, it is important to recognize that our predictive formulas as well as existing equations may not be suitable for patients at the extreme level of disease severity and neither is the commonly recommended method of indirect calorimetry, as these children commonly have ventilatory settings and treatment modalities that render this method as inaccurate. Further research in these vulnerable patients is urgently required.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: All 3 new PICU equations have R2 values of >0.8; however, equation A performed better than other predictive methods in predicting energy expenditure in these patients. Still, none of the predictive equations, including the new equations, predicted energy expenditure within a clinically accepted range, and clinicians may choose to use a simpler equation with fewer variables but with similar accuracy. Although this does not change current practice, it does indicate that even when a predictive equation has been generated from a sufficiently powered cohort, this still does not yield a formula with acceptable accuracy, and other methods should be sought, particularly for critically ill children outside the technical remits of indirect calorimetry.

ack.p: We thank the George and Sheila Livanos Charitable Trust for providing the funding for this research project. We also thank the staff on the PICU at Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust and the biomedical research unit for their support of this study and ensuring that nutrition support remains a focus of research. A special thank you also to all the parents of ventilated critically ill children who have consented to partake in this study.
